body:
Comment 14 by **jasaugusto**: 
Hi, (minux?)

I'm not familiar with assembly instructions sets for 386, 387, SSE,
SSE2 (I just programmed Intel 8085 many years ago), etc, and I'm not
also a compilation guru :-)

So I really didn't know >>all the config changes<< which had to be
done, eg, I don't know if adding a '-msse' compilation option is
enough to stop SSE2, or if one has to add '-mno-sse2', etc. If the
definition GO386=387 solves the problem, nice. Sorry but I don't know
much about the organization and compilation flow of go sources :-(.

In the end what I pretended was to get a 386 windows binary without
SSE2. I still have to test it. It runs in the modern box -- AMD
FX-8320 8-core, -- where I compiled under Windows 7 - mingw - gcc
4.6.2, -- but for that machine I have the offcial binaries, of course.
That's not the point.
